entry.title: Avoid copying AttributionTrigger when calling into storage layer
entry.content:
Instead, we move the trigger into the async storage call, and return it

back to the caller by a new field in CreateReportResult.



This avoids a potentially expensive copy of the complex nested fields of

AttributionTrigger and simultaneously simplifies observer and

debug-report usage, which take a CreateReportResult parameter anyway.



We will make an analogous change for AttributionStorage::StoreSource in

a follow-up change.

entry.title: [omnibox] Removes direct access to LocationBarModel in the omnibox code
entry.content:
Instead, OmniboxClient will act as a wrapper exposing LocationBarModel

methods currently being used in the omnibox. This change eliminates the

need for the RealboxHandler to implement LocationBarModel, allowing for

more flexibility in instantiating the RealboxHandler and embedding the

realbox in different contexts.



Additionally this CL removes a dead method, OmniboxEditModel::ShouldPreventElision().



It is worth noting that this change highlights the fact that Omnibox

uses various methods for accessing the page URL including the virtual

URL from the navigation entry, visible URL from the web content,

formatted URL for display, etc. In order to keep this change a noop,

everything is kept as is. However there may be an opportunity to

investigate consolidating those methods for improved maintainability.

entry.title: [ime] Don't block shutdown on OnScreenKeyboardDisplayManagerInputPane background tasks.
entry.content:
OnScreenKeyboardDisplayManagerInputPane's background task runner runs

tasks that wait for messages to be processed on the main thread.

However, during shutdown, the main thread stops processing messages.

As a result, tasks on OnScreenKeyboardDisplayManagerInputPane's

background task runner may hang.



With this CL, shutdown will proceed anyways (instead of preventing

process shutdown, the hung task will stop when the process exits).

entry.title: AggregationServiceStorageSql: Delete DB when error is catastrophic
entry.content:
This CL's primary change is that EnsureDatabaseOpen() will now delete

the database when opening fails due to a catastrophic SQLite error. The

probability of a encountering such an error while opening the database

is roughly one in 50,000. Methodology:



1. Compute the ratio of "Success" to the total count for histogram

"PrivacySandbox.AggregationService.Storage.Sql.InitStatus".

2. Compute the ratio of catastrophic failures to the total count for

"PrivacySandbox.AggregationService.Storage.Sql.Error". Catastrophic

errors are defined by sql::IsErrorCatastrophic().

3. Multiply the ratios (and multiply by 100 to show as a percent).



The secondary change in this CL is that the database error callback will

no longer intentionally crash debug builds. Per chromium's style

guide[0], we should be able to recover from disk corruption.



[0]: https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/main/styleguide/c++/checks.md#failures-beyond-chromium_s-control



Bug: 40948674

entry.title: Add kColorCssSystem* colors to kRendererColorIdMap
entry.content:
This CL adds the kColorCssSystem* color ids to kRendererColorIdMap,

which allows Blink to use them for css system colors. Additionally,

this CL includes the default fallback colors for these color ids in the

color pipeline.



A notable correction made in this CL is the replacement of duplicated

instances of `kColorCssSystemColorWindowText` with the correct

`kColorCssSystemColorWindow`. This error was a remnant from the initial

refactor (CL:5338343).



This is a step forward in our ongoing initiative to eliminate Blink’s

dependency on the NativeTheme for retrieving system colors.

entry.title: Handle notification actions when chrome isn't running.
entry.content:
When Chrome is launched by an App Shim to handle a notification action

click, Chrome needs to stay alive long enough to actually handle the

notification. This CL makes sure that at least Chrome stays alive long

enough.

entry.title: Ensure that PendingIntent actions are truly unique across clients
entry.content:
The change explicitly links SearchWidget actions to its surface and

request types for proper deduplication at the Launcher level.



Interesting fact: PendingIntents constructed from Intents are

deduplicated across all origins.



This means, that if a SearchWidget and QuickActionSearchWidget share

the same "intent" ("text search") but not origin, the last created

intent will overwrite definitions for the intent created before.



IOW: if the SearchWidget is the last client to create a Text search

intent, QuickAction will adopt all its extras. If QuickAction is the

last client to create that intent - it will override whatever

SearchWidget asked.



Change-Id: Ia289c508ca2c9b0acecc4c9fb885781060e824cf

Bug: 327023983

entry.title: Fix MahiPanel ContentScrollView layout
entry.content:
The `ContentScrollView`s FlexProperty was set up incorrectly

due to which it would always stick to its preferred size.

Since we already set ClipHeightTo(0, INT_MAX) for`ContentScrollView`,

setting a FlexProperty on it will have no effect.



This CL fixes this by setting the correct FlexProperty on

`ContentScrollView`s parent which uses a FillLayout.

The parent view should be configured to grow or shrink

beyond its preferred size based on available space.

entry.title: [bookmarks] Handle UUID collisions when moving bookmarks
entry.content:
If a bookmark node is moved across "storage" boundaries, i.e. the node's

value for NodeTypeForUuidLookup changes, it is possible that a UUID

collision can be hit.



This scenario is expected to be very rare in the long run, but shorter

term it is relatively easy via turning on sync-the-feature and later off,

which leads to bookmark duplicates, including duplicate UUIDs. This is

precisely the scenario reproduced in the integration tests in this patch.



The solution implemented here is to reassign the UUID for the node being

moved. The downside is that BookmarkModelObserver doesn't specifically

advertise the UUID change event, but this has no known practical

implications, and specifically it works for the main consumer of UUIDs,

which is sync code.



Change-Id: I6d2d912704872ca04f46da9ab105db45c55e50c4

Bug: 40286068

entry.title: [PIX] Add a pure virtual interface for the facilitated payment API
entry.content:
This patch adds a pure virtual interface FacilitatedPaymentsApiClient

and its delegate FacilitatedPaymentsApiClientDelegate for receiving

back the results of invoking the facilitated payment API. The

platform-agnostic code that needs to use the facilitated payment API can

get a platform specific instance of FacilitatedPaymentsApiClient by

calling FacilitatedPaymentsApiClient::Create(delegate). On Android (the

only platform where facilitated payment API is currently available),

that returns an instance of FacilitatedPaymentsApiClientAndroid, which

implements the FacilitatedPaymentsApiClient interface by invoking Java

APIs through JNI.



Bug: 329108444

entry.title: oak birch: add birch bar controller
entry.content:
This cl adds the birch bar controller to help link the model with

the birch bar in every overview grid.



Currently, the bar view directly fetches data from model. We transfer

the fetching work to birch bar controller. When the controller fetches

data from model, it will distribute the data to all birch bars.



When the user remove a chip, we will append next available item so all

fetched items may have a chance to display on the bar. Therefore, we

make BirchItem::GetItemsForDisplay return all ranked items.

entry.title: infra: Run speedometer2 across pixel6-pgo shards
entry.content:
Currently speedometer2 is only run on shard 3, not on shards 0, 1, or 2.

This results in a significant amount of variance between runs, even with

very similar builds (1-2 hours apart). Switch android-pixel6-perf-pgo to

run speedometer2 across shards instead. If this results in lower

variance then other benchmarks like jetstream2 and speedometer3 can be

spread across shards too.



The json changes in this CL were generated by running:

$ tools/perf/generate_perf_sharding.py update

And only uploading the relevant changes.

entry.title: [Nearby Presence] Add mojo::GattServer::CreateCharacteristic and impl.
entry.content:
Adds a mojo::GattServer interface and a method CreateCharacteristic().

The implementation in the browser process tries to receive a GATT

characteristic if it already exists, if not, attempts to create one.



A GattServer remote will eventually be given to the utility process in

a follow up CL to trigger calls on the GATT server. The utility process

implementation of BLE V2 is a synchronous interface used by the

Nearby Connections third_party library, which is why this mojo

method needs to be synchronous.



See full context in go/cros-nearby-ble-v2.



Tested: Verified entire chain manually via prototype in NC

entry.title: Send a single fill signal per frame per autofill operation
entry.content:
Autofill flattens forms across frames and routes all iframe forms into

their enclosing main frame form (as detailed in form_forest.h).



In case of iframes with multiple forms (multiple
elements or both

form and formless elements), this causes a preview problem because we

currently route every single filling call by itself, and every filling

call clears the preview of anything that could've happened before, which

means that in the described case only the last form that is sent to the

renderer for filling will actually be previewed.



A previous CL made the frame filling call independent of the FormData

object. This CL fixes the bug by merging all fields of same-frame forms

into a single list and sending them to the appropriate frame in a single

call.



Bug: 40943206

Change-Id: I9029b7ac635299dcdfa30590cbb0f54b7ee90d3f

Fixed: 41489087

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5331895

Reviewed-by: Christoph Schwering

Commit-Queue: Jihad Hanna

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1273550}

entry.title: [crypto] Introduce UserVerifyingKeyMac
entry.content:
Introduce an implementation of user verifying keys for macOS. This is

backed by UnexportableKeyMac.



The Windows implementation is updated to generate its own label when

creating a credential. This is easier to replicate on macOS. The

disadvantage is we will no longer be able to rely on generating keys

with the same ID resulting in replacing a previous key. Instead, a

follow-up CL will introduce the ability to delete keys by ID.



Bug: 326451282

entry.content:

IwaSourceBundleWithMode instead of a IwaSourceBundleProdMode. This

makes it easier to test the installer, and allows the dev mode

behavior to be controlled just in IsolatedWebAppInstallerCoordinator,

which will allow us more flexibility in the future.

entry.title: [UPM] Add min GMS Core version check for safety check
entry.content:
According to spec of UPM M4, Safety check should also offer to update

the Gms core version when using local store. This CL ensures that by

throwing the BACKEND_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED when there is the request to

password checkup for the local store. Then in the Safety Check mediator,

this error is converted into a user-readable message and clicking on the

Password check will result into triggering a deep link with GMS Core

update.



Bug: 321223122

entry.title: [blinkpy] Introduce `Port.test_from_output_filename(...)` (4/n)
entry.content:
This provides a way to translate a baseline path back to a test path

(i.e., the approximate inverse of `Port.output_filename()`). This is

needed to find tests affected by baseline changes in a `git` context,

including new baseline failures after a WPT import.

entry.title: Remove MainThreadScrollingReason::kNoScrollingLayer
entry.content:
Previously ScrollTree::GetMainThreadRepaintReasons() returned

kNoScrollingLayer for a ScrollNode with !is_composited &&

!main_thread_scrolling_reasons, which happened only if blink omitted

painting the transform node for a non-composited scroller [1].

0.02% (Android [1]) and 0.4% (Windows [2]) of scrolls were with

this reason.



The reason caused the scrolls to be blocked by the main thread,

but that was unnecessary because the scrollers were not visible.



Now add ScrollTree::ShouldRealizeScrollsOnMain() to replace some

!CanRealizeScrollsOnCompositor() callsites (both functions return

false if the transform node is not painted), to avoid main-thread

scroll update for invisible scrollers.



This also prepares for RasterInducingScroll which will introduce

CanRealizeScrollsOnPendingTree() (and CanRealizeScrollsOnCompositor()

will become CanRealizeScrollOnActiveTree()), which will apply for

scroll nodes with !is_composited && !main_thread_scrolling_reasons.

This CL makes it possible to repurpose the condition for scroll

nodes applicable for RasterInducingScroll.



[1] https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5368550/3/third_party/blink/renderer/platform/graphics/compositing/property_tree_manager.cc#618

[2] https://uma.googleplex.com/p/chrome/timeline_v2?sid=d5728bceab6ac2663d0474d53a08711e

[3] https://uma.googleplex.com/p/chrome/timeline_v2?sid=8eae2fe4139db6dc62d78be9bc1448de



Bug: 40256365, 40517276

Change-Id: I0b0e3b6488b980accd9a89caabcd809ea0f12169

entry.title: iwa: Add `IwaSource*WithMode::WithFileOp`, rework source inheritance
entry.content:
This CL does two things:

1. The new `IwaSource(Bundle)WithMode::WithFileOp` method closes the

missing link between sources with mode and sources with mode and file

op.

2. We previously inherited all bundle-based sources from

`IwaSourceBundle`. This was nice for sharing code and allowing

implicit conversions, but allowed you to write code like the

following, which doesn't really make sense:

```

IwaSourceBundleProdModeWithFileOp bundle;

IwaSourceBundleDevModeWithFileOp new_bundle =

bundle.WithDevModeFileOp(

IwaSourceBundleDevFileOp::kReference

);

```

With the changes in this CL, you'd have to be more explicit if you

_really_ wanted to achieve this:

```

IwaSourceBundleProdModeWithFileOp bundle;

IwaSourceBundleDevModeWithFileOp new_bundle(

bundle.path(),

IwaSourceBundleDevFileOp::kReference

);

```



Bug: None

entry.title: Revert "Enable Widevine CDM rollback on Linux/ChromeOS"
entry.content:
This reverts commit 2357f133d837df39ea8bb290edc3bcc83de7c46c.



Reason for revert: Loading the Widevine CDM on LaCros fails when

switching between rootfs and stateful file system.



Original change's description:

> Enable Widevine CDM rollback on Linux/ChromeOS

>

> Component Update allows for downgrading components to an earlier

> version. However, on Linux and ChromeOS, the Widevine CDM needs

> to be loaded before the zygote is locked, and thus uses a hint

> file to determine which version is supplied by Component Update.

> Current checking in cdm_registration uses the larger of the bundled

> version or the Component Updated version (if both exist), so if the

> downgrade is to a version prior to the current bundled version, the

> rollback doesn't work.

>

> To fix this, the hint file created when a new component is downloaded

> is updated to keep track of the bundled version at the time it was

> downloaded, as Component Update will check the bundled version when

> determining if a new version is required. If the bundled version

> matches this saved version, then the bundled version is skipped when

> checking what should be loaded into the zygote (thus always loading

> the Component Updated version).

>

> Bug: 1518051

> Test: manual test plus updated unit_tests pass

> Change-Id: I180e2b1fa125ff53f58a215a41dcd98247d92e03

> Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5251807

> Commit-Queue: John Rummell

> Reviewed-by: Xiaohan Wang

> Reviewed-by: Joshua Pawlicki

> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1260768}



Bug: 1518051, 326456139

Change-Id: I66f929a87b71f3a4e67767e1dd320fa90e4e8656

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5372935

Reviewed-by: Joshua Pawlicki

Commit-Queue: John Rummell

Reviewed-by: Xiaohan Wang

entry.title: Make HeadlessCompositorBrowserTest.CompositorImageAnimation resilient to RenderDocument
entry.content:
The aforementioned test fails with RenderDocument (but does not fail if RenderDocumentCompositorReuse is enabled). This is presumed to be due to the fact that a GIF is being animated on the impl side and thus depends on when impl frames are produced, and the old implementation without RenderDocumnet skipped commits following navigation, thus deferring beginning of the animation. With RenderDocument, a new LTH/frame sink forces frames following navigation, so animation starts earlier.



This re-writes the test so that it is resilient to whetheerDocument is enabled or not by.



The ps#2 also switches to using VirtualTimeController, which simplifies things a lot.







Change-Id: Id93b06c01a660dee50f67882259740b65c0a2311

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5373389

Reviewed-by: Rakina Zata Amni

Commit-Queue: Andrey Kosyakov

Reviewed-by: Peter Kvitek

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1273459}

entry.title: NSS: Prioritize public slot for single cert import
entry.content:
Before this CL, if the key for a cert exists on multiple slots, it’s

not specified on which one it will be imported. Change that to

prioritize the public slot.



This change is related to the effort of removing the public slot on

ChromeOS. As the first step of the migration, the PKCS#12 files

(keys + certs) are dual-written into the public and private slots.

The copies from the private slot might be deleted later if the

migration doesn’t go as planned and has to be rolled back. If

singular certs are imported for keys in the private slot, which

are later deleted, the certs will stop working. Prevent this by

prioritizing the public slot where the primary copy is currently

stored.

If the key only exists on the private slot, everything will work

the same as before this CL and such keys and certs will not be

affected by the rollback of the migration.



Testing: Create a .p12 file (key + cert1) and a different .pem cert

for the same key. Add extra logs, import the .p12 and .pem files on

the same/different public/private slots and verify the logs that it

works as expected.



Bug: b/264387231

Change-Id: If8d490531bb3f503ab85644ef708cc5d95a6d3a9

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5371993

Reviewed-by: Pavol Marko

Reviewed-by: Adam Langley

Commit-Queue: Michael Ershov

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1273458}

entry.title: [canvas] Add a feature to release recycled canvas resource
entry.content:
Due to various pipelined stages in the rendering stack (renderer-side,

GPU-side, and OS-side), when a 2D canvas is being painted, there are

multiple buffers in flight (locally, 7 buffers have been observed on a

platform with delegated compositing).



When a pipeline length changes, or when the canvas becomes static, these

buffers are eventually returned to the CanvasResourceProvider, where up

to 4 are kept around for recycling. This is similar to other such

recycling behaviors in Chromium, e.g. with cc::ResourcePool for

tiles. However, contrary to ResourcePool, there is no expiration of

unused resources in CanvasResourceProvider. Locally, on a 14 inch

macBook Pro, this has been seen to cost >100MiB for a single foreground

Google Docs tab.



This CL adds expiration and eviction of these resources, behind a

feature flag. Since reclaiming only happens after 5s of inactivity

(similar to ResourcePool), this should not impact performance-critical

workloads, while saving memory. That being said, precise cost and

benefits will be assessed with a field trial. For more details, see the

linked bug.



Bug: 326235714

Change-Id: I3962277f0c7572b3eaa487485e2f4b9a5c0b41a9

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5323842

Reviewed-by: Jean-Philippe Gravel

Commit-Queue: Benoit Lize

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1273457}

entry.title: Convert RepeatingCallback to base::FunctionRef in core/animation/.
entry.content:
This converts uses of RepeatingCallback to base::FunctionRef (which is

lower-overhead and also newer) since none of these callbacks outlive the

function calls to which they are passed. The introduction of this code

in https://crrev.com/22966a730eaf45a03d9dbfecd9b0188892442fe9 and

https://crrev.com/1c5ad7e6a3f7f41d5f8f41e2ec10eb96f8614153 predated

base::FunctionRef.
